defs.name: StreamingBodyHandle
defs.docs: A low-level interface to a streaming HTTP body.

attributes.value: / A low-level interface to a streaming HTTP body.
/ The interface to this type is very similar to `BodyHandle`, however it is write-only, and can
/ only be created as a result of calling
/ This type implements [`Write`][write] to write to the end of a body. Note that these operations are
/ unbuffered, unlike the same operations on the higher-level `Body` type.
/ `BodyHandle`s can be appended to a streaming body in amortized constant time.
/ A streaming body will be automatically closed when it goes out of scope, or when it is passed to `drop()`.

defs.name: StreamingBody
defs.docs: A streaming HTTP body that can be written to, or appended to from another body.

attributes.value: / A streaming HTTP body that can be written to, or appended to from another body.
/ The interface to this type is very similar to `Body`, however it is write-only, and can only be
/ created as a result of calling
/ The most efficient way to write the body is through the [`Write`][write] implementation. Writes are
/ buffered, but calling `Write::flush()` will flush the buffer and cause a new chunk to be written
/ A streaming body will be automatically closed when it goes out of scope, or when it is passed to `drop()`.

attributes.value: / A two-character [ISO 3166-1][iso] country code for the country associated with an IP address.
/ The US country code is returned for IP addresses associated with overseas United States military bases.
/ These values include subdivisions that are assigned their own country codes in ISO
/ 3166-1. For example, subdivisions NO-21 and NO-22 are presented with the country code SJ for
/ Svalbard and the Jan Mayen Islands.

defs.name: region
defs.docs: [ISO 3166-2][iso] country subdivision code.

attributes.value: / For countries with multiple levels of subdivision (for example, nations within the United
/ Kingdom), this variable gives the more specific subdivision.
/ This field can be `None` for countries that do not have ISO country subdivision codes. For
/ example, `None` is given for IP addresses assigned to the land Islands (country code AX,
/ Region values are the subdivision part only. For typical use, a subdivision is normally
/ formatted with its associated country code. The following example illustrates constructing
/ an [ISO 3166-2][iso] two-part country and subdivision code from the respective fields:
/ let code = if let Some(region) = geo.region() {
/ | `GB-BNH`   | Brighton and Hove | United Kingdom     | Unitary authority      |

attributes.value: / Time zone offset from coordinated universal time (UTC) for `city`.
/ This is represented using the [`FixedOffset`](struct.FixedOffset.html) type from the
/ [`chrono`][chrono] library. See `chrono`'s documentation for more details on how to format
/ this type or use it in time calculations.

/ Collect all the header values into a `Vec`:
/ To try again with a larger buffer if the first call fails, you can use
/ // Collect header values into a `Vec<HeaderValue>`, with a buffer size of `128`.
/ // If the first call fails, print our error and then try to collect header values
/ // again. The second call will use a larger buffer size of `1024`.

defs.name: append_header

/ If this [`HeaderName`][name] key already existed in the request's headers, the new

/ overwrite other pre-existing values, use [`insert_header`][insert] instead.

defs.name: send
defs.value: fn (self, body: BodyHandle, backend: &str) -> Result<(ResponseHandle, BodyHandle), Error>
defs.docs: Send a request synchronously via the given backend, blocking until the response returns.

attributes.value: / Send a request synchronously via the given backend, blocking until the response returns.

defs.name: send_async
defs.value: fn (self, body: BodyHandle, backend: &str) -> Result<PendingRequestHandle, Error>
defs.docs:
Send a request asynchronously via the given backend, returning as soon as the request has
 begun sending.

attributes.value: / Send a request asynchronously via the given backend, returning as soon as the request has
/ [`select_handles`](fn.select_handles.html). It can also be discarded if the request was sent
/ for effects it might have, and the response is unimportant.

defs.name: send_async_streaming
defs.value: fn (self, body: BodyHandle, backend: &str) -> Result<(StreamingBodyHandle, PendingRequestHandle), Error>
defs.docs:
Send a request asynchronously via the given backend, and return a
 [`StreamingBodyHandle`][streaming-body] to allow continued writes to the request body.

attributes.value: / Send a request asynchronously via the given backend, and return a
/ [`StreamingBodyHandle`][streaming-body] to allow continued writes to the request body.
/ The resulting `StreamingBodyHandle` must be dropped in order to finish sending the request.

attributes.value: / An error that occurred while sending a request.
/ In practice this error should arise very rarely, usually due to a misconfigured request. Most
/ errors that arise during the actual connection to the backend will be returned as `Ok` values
/ While the body of a request is always consumed when sent, you can recover the headers and other
/ request metadata of the request that failed using `SendError::into_sent_req()`.

attributes.value: / Given a collection of [`PendingRequestHandle`](struct.PendingRequestHandle.html)s, block until
/ the result of one of the handles is ready.
/ This function accepts any type which can become an iterator that yields handles; a common choice
/ Returns a tuple `(result, index, remaining)`, where:
/ - `result` is the result of the handle that became ready.
/ - `index` is the index of the handle in the argument collection (e.g., the index of the handle
/ in a vector) that became ready.
/ - `remaining` is a vector containing all of the handles that did not become ready. The order of
/ the handles in this vector is not guaranteed to match the order of the handles in the argument
/ Panics if the argument collection is empty, or contains more than
